data.title: Cullen/Frost Bankers Inc reports results for the quarter ended September 30 - Earnings Summary
data.description:
• Cullen/Frost Bankers Inc reported quarterly adjusted earnings of $2.67ââ per share for the quarter ended September 30, higher than the same quarter last year, when the company reported EPS of $2.24. The mean expectation of sixteen analysts for the quarter was for earnings of $2.38 per share. Wall Street expected results to range from $2.29 to $2.49 per share.

  • Revenue rose 29.8% to $567.27 million from a year ago; analysts expected $565.55 million.

  • Cullen/Frost Bankers Inc's reported EPS for the quarter was $2.67â.

  • The company reported quarterly net income of $172.71 million.

  • Cullen/Frost Bankers Inc shares had fallen by 4.2% this quarter and lost 9.6% so far this year.

FORECAST CHANGES

  • The mean earnings estimate of analysts had risen by about 0.9% in the last three months.â

  • In the last 30 days, two analysts negatively revised earnings estimates

RECOMMENDATIONS

  • The current average analyst rating on the shares is "hold" and the breakdown of recommendations is 5 "strong buy" or "buy," 8 "hold" and 3 "sell" or "strong sell." The average consensus recommendation for the banks peer group is "buy."

  • Wall Street's median 12-month price target for Cullen/Frost Bankers Inc is $139.00, about 12.7% above its last closing price of $121.41

This summary was machine generated from LSEG data October 30 at 02:36 p.m. UTC. âAll figures in US dollars unless otherwise stated. data.title: Rollins Up Over 6%, on Pace for Largest Percent Increase Since October 2022 â Data Talk
data.description:
Rollins, Inc. (ROL) is currently at $57.37, up $3.50 or 6.5%

  • Would be highest close since Oct. 8, 2025, when it closed at $58.12
  • On pace for largest percent increase since Oct. 26, 2022, when it rose 10.04%
  • Snaps a four day losing streak
  • Down 2.33% month-to-date; on pace for worst month since Dec. 2024, when it fell 7.91%
  • Up 23.78% year-to-date; on pace for best year since 2020, when it rose 76.73%
  • Down 2.33% from its all-time closing high of $58.74 on Sept. 30, 2025
  • Up 21.7% from 52 weeks ago (Oct. 31, 2024), when it closed at $47.14
  • Down 2.33% from its 52-week closing high of $58.74 on Sept. 30, 2025
  • Up 25.67% from its 52-week closing low of $45.65 on Jan. 6, 2025
  • Traded as high as $57.47
  • Up 6.68% at today's intraday high; largest intraday percent increase since Oct. 26, 2023, when it rose as much as 10.69%
  • Seventh best performer in the S&P 500 today

All data as of 10:34:04 AM ET

Source: Dow Jones Market Data, FactSet

data.title: Digital Bank Monzo Hires New CEO Ahead of IPO, Sky News Says, Citing Sources
data.description:
• Digital bank Monzo has appointed a new chief executive ahead of a possible initial public offering that could value the business at up to 10 billion pounds ($13.19 billion), Sky News reports, citing unnamed sources.
  • Monzo appointed Diana Layfield as its new CEO, Sky reports. Layfield is a former Google and Standard Chartered executive.
  • The company is considering a listing in either London or New York, Sky says, adding that London is the most likely venue.
  • Monzo declined to comment to Sky.

Full story: https://tinyurl.com/ywcmbret

Write to Ian Walker at ian.walker@wsj.com

data.title: Trump and Xi Reach Rare-Earths Deal. Why MP Materials Stock Is Falling. â Barrons.com
data.description:
By Callum Keown

MP Materials and other rare-earths stocks traded higher in premarket trading Thursday even as the U.S. and China reached an agreement over export controls of the critical materials.

President Donald Trump and China's leader Xi Jinping met for talks in South Korea and managed to resolve a number of issues between the two countries. China agreed to defer its plan to tighten export controls on rare-earth materials for a year. A commerce ministry spokesperson said Beijing will "study and refine specific plans" in the meantime, reported state-owned news agency Xinhua reported.

MP Materials stock, which is up 312% this year through Wednesday, rose 3.3% ahead of the open, while USA Rare Earth jumped 5.9% and Ramaco Resources rose 0.9%.

All three fell sharply in the run-up to the meeting between Trump and Xi as it had been expected an agreement of some sorts would be reached. The prospect of tighter curbs, unveiled by China in October, essentially sparked the rally in rare-earths stocks in the first place.

Maybe it's a case of "sell the rumor, buy the news," or perhaps it's because the agreement only defers China tightened curbs for a year--even if the expectation is that they won't come into effect. The sector has also been particularly volatile in recent months.

Separately, shares of critical minerals company NioCorp Developments were up 2.8% ahead of the open.

Rare-earth materials are used to produce magnets essential for a range of industries, including the technology, autos, defense and renewable energy sectors.

China dominates the rare earth industry with an estimated 85% of global processing capacity. But the tensions have put the spotlight on just how important the industry is and they've sparked efforts to reduce the U.S.'s dependence on China.

Trump said the agreement brings an end to the "rare earths roadblock," but it doesn't have to be the end of the stocks' rally.

Write to Callum Keown at callum.keown@dowjones.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Russia's Lukoil to Sell International Assets to Gunvor in Wake of U.S. Sanctions â WSJ
data.description:
By Rebecca Feng

Russia's Lukoil has agreed to sell its international assets to commodities trader Gunvor after the energy giant was hit by new U.S. sanctions last week.

The details

Lukoil said Thursday that it had accepted an offer from Gunvor to purchase Lukoil International, which holds the company's assets across more than 30 countries.

The company didn't disclose the value or timeline of the deal, but said the key terms of the transaction had been agreed by both parties.

Lukoil, Russia's second-largest oil producer, said the sale was prompted by "restrictive measures of some states introduced against the company and its subsidiaries."

The deal is set to hand Gunvor an extensive portfolio of upstream and downstream assets, including major projects in Egypt, Azerbaijan and Uzbekistan. Lukoil also has a 75% stake in the West Qurna 2 oil project in Iraq, one of the world's largest oil fields producing hundreds of thousands of barrels a day.

Overall, Lukoil's international assets â excluding the Iraqi project â make up about 5% of the company's total oil production, according to its 2024 annual report.

Gunvor will also take control of Lukoil's refineries and gas stations across the globe, including the U.S.

Lukoil has an international trading arm, called Litasco, which ferries the company's crude and fuel around the world. The sale doesn't include Litasco's Dubai unit, which was sanctioned by the U.K. in July for its role in moving Russian oil on so-called "shadow fleet" vessels.

The deal is subject to Gunvor obtaining approval from the U.S. Office of Foreign Assets Control, as well as licenses and permits in other jurisdictions.

The context

President Trump imposed new sanctions on Lukoil and its peer Rosneft last Wednesday, as Washington grew frustrated with Russia over the war in Ukraine.

The fresh measures â the first direct U.S. measures on Russia during the second Trump administration â ban foreign countries and companies from conducting business with the two oil companies, and cut them off from the U.S. financial system.

In response, Lukoil quickly announced that it planned to sell its international assets.

Gunvor is a Western player with connections and experience in Russia. However, the deal will also see the company venture into areas where it has limited experience, such as oil production and gas stations.

Gunvor was co-founded by Swedish billionaire TorbjÃ¶rn TÃ¶rnqvist and Russian businessman Gennady Timchenko, a former Soviet trade official and a member of the Russian president's inner circle.

In 2014, the Obama administration sanctioned Timchenko and said the Russian President Vladimir Putin had investments in Gunvor, an allegation that Gunvor called "outrageous." Within 24 hours, TÃ¶rnqvist bought Timchenko's 43% stake in Gunvor. The firm went on to sell some of its port terminal and pipeline assets in Russia and established new businesses elsewhere.

Write to Rebecca Feng at rebecca.feng@wsj.com

data.title: Burger King Brings Some Flame to U.S. Sales â WSJ
data.description:
By Heather Haddon

Burger King's U.S. results are improving, and executives say they aren't resorting to discounts like rivals to bring in Whopper fans.

The burger chain's U.S. same-store sales increased 3.2% in its three months ended Sept. 30, accelerating from the prior quarter, and executives said Burger King is now outpacing many burger rivals and U.S. fast-food as a whole.

"We've got a lot of innings to work through on Burger King, but we're very comfortable that we're seeing the results," said Patrick Doyle, executive chairman of chain parent Restaurant Brands International. The company's shares rose 2.5% in morning trading.

CEO Josh Kobza said that Burger King's $5 and $7 deals helped drive sales, but the chain is staying disciplined on discounts. McDonald's slashed prices on its combo meals in September, and will report third-quarter results next week.

This item is part of a Wall Street Journal live coverage event. The full stream can be found by searching P/WSJL (WSJ Live Coverage).

data.title: Cardinal Health lifts annual adjusted profit forecast on specialty drug demand
data.description:
By Siddhi Mahatole

Drug distributor Cardinal Health raised its annual adjusted profit forecast on Thursday after beating estimates for first-quarter profit on strong demand for costly specialty medicines and branded drugs at its pharmaceuticals unit.

Shares of the Dublin, Ohio-based company rose 17.7% in early trading.

Drug distributors have been benefiting from sales of specialty medicines, which are used to treat complex conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and cancer, due to their high profit margins.

They have also benefited from sales of cheaper versions of complex biotech drugs called biosimilars at a time when prices of generic medicines have been falling due to intense competition.

Cardinal now expects adjusted profit per share in a range of $9.65 to $9.85 for fiscal 2026, up from its prior range of $9.30 to $9.50.

The company said the 35-cent increase reflects its strong first-quarter performance. It anticipates contributions from its pending acquisition of Solaris Health that is expected to close in early November.

"We expect M&A to contribute about 8 percentage points to pharma profit growth in fiscal 2026," said CFO Aaron Alt, adding the company expects the first half to be stronger than the second half, driven by new customers.

Cardinal Health said in August it would buy healthcare management firm Solaris Health for $1.9 billion in cash.

Cardinal reported quarterly adjusted profit of $2.55 per share, beating analysts' estimate of $2.18 per share, according to LSEG data.

Its quarterly revenue came in at $64 billion, above the $59.20 billion estimate.

Leerink Partners analyst Michael Cherny said pre-quarter concerns around the company's first quarter - largely stemming from its comments about the timing of vaccine shipments - were "overblown".

"Even with that dynamic, we did not see this magnitude of beat across the enterprise coming," Cherny said.

The company's Pharmaceutical and Specialty Solutions segment generated $59.2 billion in revenue for the quarter ended September 30, up 23% year-over-year.

data.title: Extra Space Storage hits year low on weak 2025 FFO outlook
data.description:
** Shares of self-storage facilities operator Extra Space Storage fall 7% to $132 in early trading, the lowest in a year

** Co forecast 2025 core funds from operations (FFO) below Wall Street estimates on Wednesday due to continued pressure from sluggish same-store growth

** It expects annual core FFO between $8.12 and $8.20 per share, the midpoint of which is below analysts' avg. estimate of $8.18 according to data compiled by LSEG

** Co's key challenges include regaining pricing power and offsetting the impact of shifting occupancy trends

** Co posted Q3 revenue of $858.5 mln, above estimates of $779.9 mln

** Its quarterly core FFO of $2.08/share was in line with estimates

** Including session's move, shares down 11.6% YTD

data.title: Merck falls after narrowing annual revenue forecast
data.description:
** Shares of drugmaker Merck fall 2% to $84.84 in early trading

** Co narrows revenue outlook for the full year to $64.5 billion-$65.0 billion vs prior forecast of $64.3 billion to $65.3 billion

** Co reports Q3 adj. profit of $2.58/share vs analysts' average estimate of $2.35/share - data compiled by LSEG

** MRK's quarterly revenue of $17.28 billion beats analysts' average expectation of $16.96 billion

** MRK's cancer therapy Keytruda post 10% rise in sales to $8.1 bln, in line with consensus

** Co's human papillomavirus vaccine Gardasil's sales fell to $1.75 bln, ahead of $1.66 bln estimate; Co says China distributors working through inventory

** Including session's move, stock down 14% YTD

data.title: Core Scientific terminates $9 billion merger deal with CoreWeave
data.description: Crypto miner Core Scientific on Thursday ended its merger agreement with Nvidia-backed CoreWeave .

data.title: Quanta Services up after lifting annual revenue forecast
data.description:
** Shares of energy contractor Quanta Services rise 1.6% to about $456 in early trade

** Co lifts FY revenue forecast citing demand acceleration in the larger electric segment

** Expects FY revenue between $27.8 bln and $28.2 bln, up from $27.4 bln to $27.9 bln earlier

** Narrows FY adj EPS forecast to $10.33 to $10.83, from its prior view of $10.28 to $10.88

** Co benefits as surging power demand in the U.S. fuels its electric and renewables business

** Posts Q3 adj EPS of $3.33, beating Wall Street estimate of $3.26 - data compiled by LSEG

** Reports quarterly revenue of $7.63 bln, beating estimates of $7.39 bln

** Including session's moves, shares up 43.7% YTD

data.title: Recover Investment Losses: Class Action Initiated Against MoonLake Immunotherapeutics (MLTX)
data.description:
NEW YORK, NY / ACCESS Newswire / October 30, 2025 / If you suffered a loss on your MoonLake Immunotherapeutics investment and want to learn about a potential recovery under the federal securities laws, follow the link below for more information:

https://zlk.com/pslra-1/moonlake-lawsuit-submission-form?prid=174735&wire=1&utm_campaign=24

or contact Joseph E. Levi, Esq. via email at jlevi@levikorsinsky.com or call (212) 363-7500 to speak to our team of experienced shareholder advocates.

THE LAWSUIT: A class action securities lawsuit was filed against MoonLake Immunotherapeutics that seeks to recover losses of shareholders who were adversely affected by alleged securities fraud between March 10, 2024 and September 29, 2025.

CASE DETAILS: The filed complaint alleges that defendants made false statements and/or concealed that: (1) It's sole drug candidate, SLK and BIMZELX share the same molecular targets (the inflammatory cytokines IL-17A and IL-17F); (2) SLK's distinct Nanobody structure would not confer a superior clinical benefit over the traditional monoclonal structure of BIMZELX; (3) SLK's distinct Nanobody structure supposed increased tissue penetration would not translate to clinical efficacy; and (4) based on the foregoing, defendants lacked a reasonable basis for their positive statements regarding SLK's purported superiority to monoclonal antibodies.

WHAT'S NEXT? If you suffered a loss in MoonLake stock during the relevant time frame - even if you still hold your shares - go to https://zlk.com/pslra-1/moonlake-lawsuit-submission-form?prid=174735&wire=1&utm_campaign=24 to learn about your rights to seek a recovery. There is no cost or obligation to participate.

WHY LEVI & KORSINSKY: Over the past 20 years, Levi & Korsinsky LLP has established itself as a nationally-recognized securities litigation firm that has secured hundreds of millions of dollars for aggrieved shareholders and built a track record of winning high-stakes cases. The firm has extensive expertise representing investors in complex securities litigation and a team of over 70 employees to serve our clients. For seven years in a row, Levi & Korsinsky has ranked in ISS Securities Class Action Services' Top 50 Report as one of the top securities litigation firms in the United States. Attorney Advertising. Prior results do not guarantee similar outcomes.

CONTACT:

Levi & Korsinsky, LLP

Joseph E. Levi, Esq.

Ed Korsinsky, Esq.

33 Whitehall Street, 27th Floor

New York, NY 10004

jlevi@levikorsinsky.com

Tel: (212) 363-7500

Fax: (212) 363-7171

https://zlk.com/

SOURCE: Levi & Korsinsky, LLP

data.title: Core Scientific, Inc. Announces Preliminary Results of Special Meeting
data.description:
On October 30, 2025, Core Scientific, Inc. announced it did not receive enough votes to approve its merger with CoreWeave, Inc.

Key Highlights:

  • Special meeting held to vote on merger with CoreWeave.
  • Merger agreement did not receive necessary stockholder approval.
  • Final voting results to be reported in a future SEC filing.

Original SEC Filing: Core Scientific, Inc./tx [ CORZ ] - 8-K - Oct. 30, 2025

data.title: Solera Receives Offer Letter
data.description:
Chairman Quagliano motioned that the unredacted offer letter and letter of intent be published publicly on the website, via press release, and included in the proxy letter. J. Wright suggested that language be added to the press release and notification stating, essentially, "The Board received this unsolicited offer and found it to be grossly inadequate."

LAKEWOOD, CO / ACCESS Newswire / October 30, 2025 / Board of Directors

Solera National Bancorp, Inc. c/o Chairman Michael Drew Quagliano

319 South Sheridan Boulevard Lakewood, CO 80226

Re:

Non-Binding Indication of Interest - Proposed Purchase of 100% of the Outstanding Common Stock of Solera National Bancorp, Inc.

Ladies and Gentlemen:

On behalf of Project Sun Holdings, LLC (the "Buyer"), a Delaware limited liability company to be formed, and certain institutional co-investors (collectively, "Buyer Group"), we are pleased to submit this non-binding indication of interest (this "Indication" or "NBO") for the proposed acquisition of one hundred percent (100%) of the outstanding common stock of Solera National Bancorp, Inc. (the "Company" or "Solera"), the parent company of Solera National Bank (the "Bank").

This Indication is intended to set out the principal terms upon which the Buyer Group would be prepared to pursue a transaction and to facilitate discussions between the parties. Except as expressly stated below with respect to confidentiality and exclusivity, this Indication is non-binding and is subject to, among other things, negotiation, documentation and the execution of definitive agreements acceptable to the parties.

  • Buyer Group

Buyer will act through NewCo (Project Sun Holdings, LLC), to be formed in Delaware, and will be supported by committed co-investors comprised of institutional partners. Buyer will provide proof of funds and evidence of equity commitments upon the Company's reasonable request.

  • Proposed Transaction

Buyer proposes to acquire 100% of the outstanding shares of the Company by way of an all-cash stock purchase of the Company's issued and outstanding common stock, on the terms described herein and subject to customary adjustments and the conditions set forth below.

  • Purchase Price

Buyer proposes an aggregate purchase price of US$70,000,000 ( Seventy Million Dollars) (the "Purchase Price"), payable in cash at the Closing, subject to customary adjustments for:

  • Net working capital (target and true-up mechanics to be agreed);

  • Loan portfolio adjustments deriving from confirmatory review of loan tapes, ACL adequacy, non-performing assets and TDRs; and

  • Permitted post-closing adjustments agreed in the definitive purchase agreement.

The Purchase Price represents approximately a 70.6% premium to the thirty (30)-day average price of Solera common stock of $9.54, as of September 24, 2025, and is intended as a firm, single-number offer for purposes of this Indication.

  • Form of Consideration and Escrow

  • Form: All cash at Closing, subject to the adjustments described above.

  • Escrow / Holdback: Buyer proposes that a portion of the Purchase Price equal to fifteen percent (15%) be held in escrow (or otherwise retained) to secure seller representations, warranties and indemnities for a period of up to twenty-four (24) months (or such other arrangement as the parties agree). The specific escrow mechanics, claims process and release schedule will be negotiated in definitive documentation.

  • Financing and Proof of Funds

Buyer has obtained firm equity commitments from lead investors and stands ready to fund the Purchase Price from equity and / or committed financing sources. Buyer will promptly provide reasonable evidence of financing and proof of funds upon execution of a confidentiality and exclusivity agreement and prior to the commencement of confirmatory due diligence.

  • Conditions to Closing

The proposed transaction will be subject to customary closing conditions, including, without limitation:

  • Satisfactory confirmatory due diligence (financial, legal, regulatory, tax, BSA/AML, IT and operational, without limitation) at the Buyer's reasonable judgment;

  • Execution of mutually acceptable definitive agreements, including a stock purchase agreement containing customary representations, warranties, covenants, indemnities, closing conditions and termination rights;

  • No material adverse change in the business, operations, financial condition or prospects of the Company and the Bank prior to Closing;

  • Receipt of all required regulatory approvals and non-objections, including (without limitation):

o OCC non-objection under the Change in Bank Control Act (12 U.S.C. Â§1817(j)) and implementing regulations (12 C.F.R. Â§5.50), with Buyer filing required prior notices promptly following execution of a definitive agreement; o Any additional approvals or clearances required by the Federal Reserve,

FDIC or other applicable regulators; and o Hart-Scott-Rodino (HSR) clearance, if applicable; and

  • Shareholder approval, if required under applicable law or the Company's organizational documents.

Buyer acknowledges and understands that OCC review and non-objection will be required before Closing and that the statutory waiting period under applicable rules is a gating regulatory requirement.

  • Timeline (Indicative)

Buyer proposes the following indicative timing, subject to the Company's cooperation in providing diligence access and to regulatory timing:

  • Offer Validity: This Indication is open for acceptance until 5:00 p.m. Eastern Time on October 3rd, 2025 (the "Expiration Date"), unless earlier withdrawn by Buyer.

  • Exclusivity / Diligence : Upon mutual execution of a confidentiality and exclusivity agreement, Buyer requests an exclusivity period of ninety (90) days for purposes of confirmatory due diligence and negotiation of definitive agreements.

  • Definitive Agreement: Buyer aims to execute a binding stock purchase agreement within forty-five (45) days of acceptance of this Indication.

  • Regulatory Filing & Closing: Buyer will promptly submit required regulatory notice(s) following execution of definitive documentation. Subject to regulatory timing and approvals, Buyer would expect to close within 30-60 days following receipt of applicable regulatory non-objection(s), though actual timing may be longer depending on regulators' review.

  • Due Diligence Scope

This Indication is based on the information available to the Buyer as of today. Confirmatory diligence will include, without limitation: loan tapes and credit files, underwriting and collateral schedules, ACL methodology, deposit composition, core processor agreements, BSA/AML program, CRA matters and exam history, employee and executive agreements, litigation and regulatory matters, tax and environmental matters, IT systems, and any material contracts. Buyer will require access to management and to data rooms and will follow customary diligence protocols regarding confidentiality and limited distribution.

  • Confidentiality and Exclusivity

  • Confidentiality: The contents of this Indication and any subsequent discussions shall be treated as strictly private and confidential and are intended solely for the information of the recipients and their professional advisers eventually retained for the purposes of the Proposed Transaction. Neither the Buyer's interest in the Company nor the content of this NBO shall be disclosed to any person other than the recipients' professional advisers without the Buyer's prior written consent.

  • Exclusivity: To permit Buyer to devote time and resources to confirmatory diligence and negotiation of definitive agreements, Buyer requests that the Company grant Buyer exclusive negotiation rights for ninety (90) days upon mutual execution of a short confidentiality/exclusivity agreement; such exclusivity shall be binding and subject to the terms of the confidentiality/exclusivity agreement to be executed by the parties.

  • Material Adverse Change / Interim Covenants

Pending execution of definitive agreements, Buyer requests that the Company refrain from taking extraordinary actions (including dividend declarations, significant asset dispositions, material incurrence of indebtedness, or entering into material related-party transactions) without Buyer's prior written consent, except as otherwise required by law or regulation.

  • Legal Effect; Non-Binding Nature

This Indication is non-binding, other than the Confidentiality and Exclusivity provisions expressly referenced above (which shall be binding if and when the parties execute a separate confidentiality/exclusivity agreement). No obligation of any kind (including any obligation to consummate the transaction) will arise unless and until definitive agreements have been executed and delivered by the parties and all conditions therein have been satisfied or waived. This Indication does not constitute a solicitation for proxies or a public offer.

  • Governing Law

This Indication and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with it shall be governed in all respects, including existence, validity, interpretation and effect (without regard to principles of conflicts of law) by the laws of New York, USA.

Any dispute howsoever deriving or arising from this Indication or in connection with the

Proposed Transaction shall be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the Courts of Delaware, USA.

  • Closing Remarks

Buyer believes this proposal offers a prompt, certain and well-capitalized path to a transaction that protects the interests of the Company's stakeholders, preserves franchise value and positions the Bank for operational and capital improvement under experienced stewardship. Buyer looks forward to the opportunity to discuss this Indication with the Board and to proceed in an expedited and cooperative manner.

If the Board is receptive to this Indication, we respectfully request a meeting with the Board and management at the earliest feasible date to present our proposal and to review next steps, including execution of a confidentiality/exclusivity agreement to permit confirmatory due diligence.

Sincerely,

/ / /

Mr. Davi Cunha

Davi Cunha

Sponsor / Authorized Signatory

Project Sun Holdings, LLC (NewCo to be formed)

Michael Quagliano

Executive Chairman of the Company & Board

Solera National Bancorp, Inc

Contacts:

Jay Hansen,

CFO

(303) 209-8600

SOURCE: Solera National Bancorp, Inc.

View the original press release on ACCESS Newswire

data.title: Inflation Risks to Keep Gold Attractive, Weaken Bonds â Market Talk
data.description:
1030 ET - Inflation risks remain, as Fed Chair Powell made clear yesterday, and it could be a reason to sell bonds and buy gold. "You still want to have gold as a diversifier...because inflation risks are still higher than they have been for many years," Harbor Capital's Jake Schurmeier says, adding that "inflation is the worst thing for bonds." Among potential inflation boosters he lists "questions about Fed credibility [and] too much cyclical fiscal stimulus." Schurmeier is overweight equities, while adding small caps, eyeing a pickup in economic activity. A weakening dollar, meanwhile, makes non-U.S. assets more appealing, Schurmeier says. (paulo.trevisani@wsj.com; @ptrevisani)

1023 ET - Yields on U.K. government bonds climb, tracking their U.S. peers, as markets revise down their expectations for U.S. interest-rate cuts after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said a follow-up rate reduction in December wasn't a foregone conclusion. On top of that, the European Central Bank left interest rates on hold on Thursday, as expected, and stressed the recent resilience of the eurozone economy despite an uncertain outlook. Ten-year gilt yields rise 3.5 basis points to last trade at 4.430%, Tradeweb data show. Ten-year U.S. Treasury yields rise by around the same amount to 4.095%. (miriam.mukuru@wsj.com)

1019 ET - The typical U.S. luxury home sold for $1.26 million in September, up 4.8% from a year earlier, Redfin says, a record high for the month. That's more than twice the pace of price growth for non-luxury homes, which rose 1.8% year-over-year to a median of $371,583. The typical luxury home price has climbed about 11% since September 2023, compared with roughly 6% growth for non-luxury homes. People buying at the top end aren't waiting for rates to drop or prices to fall, Redfin says. They have the cash, stock gains, and long-term confidence to act when they see a home they want. Some high-end buyers are using real estate as a safe place to park their money amid economic uncertainty. High-end buyers also tend to pay in cash or take smaller loans, Redfin says. (chris.wack@wsj.com)

1015 ET - The median U.S. monthly housing payment was $2,530 during the four weeks ending Oct. 26, Redfin says, down 1.4% year over year. Monthly payments fell as mortgage rates declined. The weekly average mortgage rate dropped to 6.19% this week, its lowest level in over a year. Falling mortgage rates are enough to push monthly payments down despite rising sale prices. The median U.S. home-sale price rose 1.9% year over year, the second-biggest increase in six months. Pending home sales are up 1% year over year, and mortgage-purchase applications are up 5% week over week. New listings are up 4.6% year over year, the biggest uptick in five months, as sellers hope buyers will pounce on lower rates. (chris.wack@wsj.com)

1003 ET - The European Central Bank's decision to leave its deposit rate unchanged at 2.0% and offer no guidance for future rate decisions was exactly as expected, Capital Economics' Jack Allen-Reynolds says in a note. However, activity and inflation data in 2026 could eventually prompt it to cut interest rates, he says. "The key point is that there is little appetite on the Governing Council to change interest rates in the near term, and we agree with market pricing that the deposit rate is likely stay at 2% over the next six months or so." But growth is set to remain subdued and inflation fall further below the 2% target than most anticipate, says Allen-Reynolds, who pencils in two rate cuts next year. (edward.frankl@wsj.com)

0956 ET - The market could be underpricing the prospect of another interest-rate cut by the European Central Bank in December or the first half of 2026, Goldman Sachs Asset Management's Simon Dangoor says in a note. The comment comes after the ECB held rates steady, as expected. Data remain mixed, while the rollout of Germany's fiscal expansion could be slow, reducing growth prospects and providing a counterargument for policymakers who favor keeping rates unchanged, he says. "December's meeting brings with it 2028 economic projections; if they show inflation undershooting three years in a row, the doves will be pressing the case for a cut sooner rather than later." (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

0944 ET - Eurozone government bond yields are little moved, staying higher on the day after the European Central Bank left policy rates unchanged, as expected. The 10-year Bund yield last trades at 2.657%, up 3.8 basis points after the decision. Eurozone bond yields have been driven higher by rising U.S. Treasury yields after the Federal Reserve cooled market expectations of another rate cut in December. Meanwhile, the ECB pointed to a resilient economy. "Despite the U.S. tariffs, despite all the various sources of uncertainty, the European economy continues to eke out some growth," says Mark Wall, chief European economist at Deutsche Bank. "Economic 'resilience' is keeping the ECB doves in check, and the policy pause on the rails," he says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

0936 ET - The euro recovers slightly against the dollar after the European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged as expected. The ECB said the economy has continued to grow despite a challenging global environment. It also pointed to a robust labor market, solid private sector balance sheets and past rate cuts as "important sources of resilience" but noted that the outlook remains uncertain given global trade disputes and geopolitical tensions. The ECB reiterated a data-dependent, meeting-by-meeting approach to future decisions. The euro falls 0.3% to $1.1564. It hit a two-week low of $1.1546 just before the decision as the dollar strengthened in the wake of the Federal Reserve signalling a December rate cut wasn't a done deal alongside a highly-anticipated 25 basis-point cut on Wednesday. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

0933 ET - Rising Treasury yields support the dollar, Bannockburn's Marc Chandler says. Bonds are selling off since Fed Chair Powell said that an interest rate cut in December can't be taken for granted. It is unclear whether overnight news of improving U.S.-China trade relations, after the Trump-Xi meeting, is having any impact on FX markets. "I think it is hard to separate the trade story and Fed hawkish cut in driving [the] dollar," Chandler says, adding that markets had already been optimistic about a deal. The Bank of Japan stays put, as expected. The WSJ Dollar Index rises 0.5% as the greenback strengthens 1% versus the yen and 0.5% against the euro. (paulo.trevisani@wsj.com; @ptrevisani)

0925 ET - Signs of weakness in Canada's labor market continue to roll in, with data showing little change in payroll numbers in August and a drop in job vacancies to the lowest level since the same month in 2017. The number of Canadians receiving pay and benefits from an employer ticked up 3,300 for the month, marking no change on a percentage basis, after edging up 0.1% in July. Compared with a year earlier, payroll employment was up 31,500, or 0.2%. Gains were noted by Statistics Canada in public administration and construction, but declines in retail, wholesale and scientific and technical services. Job vacancies in August fell 2.4% to 457,400, and were 15.2% lower than a year earlier. That meant 3.5 unemployed persons for every job vacancy in August. (robb.stewart@wsj.com; @RobbMStewart)

0903 ET - Sterling could recover against the Swiss franc after falling to a three-year low Wednesday, Morgan Stanley strategists say in a note. The exchange rate remains attractive in carry trades where investors borrow in low-yielding currencies to invest in higher-yielding ones, they say. Moreover, markets are pricing in too much risk premium ahead of next month's U.K. budget and the rise in Bank of England interest rate cut expectations looks overdone, they say. Finally, the franc has strengthened too much against the euro. Morgan Stanley has a target for sterling to rise to 1.15 francs, with a stop loss of 1.0159 francs. Sterling falls 0.1% to 1.0544 francs, having reached a low of 1.0493 Wednesday, according to LSEG. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

0851 ET - Economist David Rosenberg believes the Bank of Canada may eventually have to cut rates again, despite their signal that the easing cycle might be done. The head of Rosenberg Research points to a line from Gov. Tiff Macklem's press conference, in which Macklem suggests tepid growth means "excess supply is only taken up gradually." This indicates a disinflationary environment, he adds, "and a telltale sign that the BOC is not yet done... Yes, the BOC thinks it has done enough but they are clearly unsure." Rosenberg adds the overall tone of the BOC's suite of communications was more dovish than in September "and rather negative on the economic outlook." (Paul.Vieira@wsj.com; @paulvieira)
